column36: The most difficult thing for me about this experience was lesson planning. Especially in the first semester, I felt very unprepared for lesson planning. I would scour the internet for resources, and look through the book, but nothing seemed designed for the level of our students and their age. For example, resources that were at their level would be aimed at 2-3 year olds, and resources that were age appropriate would be aimed at almost fluent speakers, but rarely would resources be age appropriate AND assume a low level of competency.    I confronted this challenge by reading a couple TEFL books (the Teach For America "Instructional Planning and Delivery" guide, available online, changed the game for me. Jeremy Harper's "How to Teach English" was also a great resource), and by meeting with the WorldTeach Director of Education (Matthew) multiple times. When Melissa became our FD, I met with her a couple times, and she was supremely helpful in helping me be more efficient.

column38: More time spent lesson planning does not necessarily correlate with better lessons. There is a point at which you are agonizing over details and not actually improving the lesson. If possible, try to teach the same lesson to multiple classes, and refine the lesson each time you teach it based on what you notice works and does not work. Don't be afraid to try new things and to experiment. Start with a base of "cookie cutter" activities that you can draw from, and then incorporate your own creative ideas. Get the students talking as much as you can, and reduce the amount of time you lecture/talk to a minimum. Do your best to make the rules for an activity intuitive -- imagine a student wasn't listening; can they still figure out what to do? Don't pack a lot -- you can get almost anything you need here, either in your town or in Nakhon Phanom. When you're offered a new food, or something unique/funny happens, when you're teaching something new in class -- ask your students how you say it in Thai. It really goes a long way to showing you're interested in their culture too. Try to incorporate the Thai you learn this way into your conversations throughout the year, even if it's 99% English and 1% Thai. Get out of your house; don't hide away in your farang comforts. Even if you want to work, go outside in the shade somewhere, or to a cafe. Go work at your school, or at a neighbor's house. Be available. If you can afford it, when you go buy coffee/tea, get an extra one and give it to a colleague.
column40: I got out a lot out of my year, and overall it was a positive experience. I did however want to mention a few things that could improve the experience for volunteers in the future, and also improve WorldTeach's reputation in Thailand.    Several of our volunteers expressed from the very beginning that the main reason they were here was "to have fun." That mindset explained some of the immaturity in our group this year, from people being very late to PLCs, missing PLCs and not submitting lesson plans or making up the PLC, and in at least one case, being actively disrespectful to hotel staff which resulted in someone getting accosted by police in the beginning of the year. Volunteers were rarely held accountable (in the first half of the year), and by the second month of teaching, I heard volunteers say things like "what are they going to do, fire me?" I took this commitment very seriously (in some ways, maybe too seriously), and I know I can be high-strung, but that kind of behavior made me feel like this service wasn't as important as I thought it was. Probably WorldTeach gets a limited pool of applicants each year, so it might not be possible to vet applicants anymore than you already do. Instead, having more language in the application materials and during orientation (and throughout the program) about the seriousness of the commitment could help.    Socially, I wish our group had been encouraged to be more cohesive, to reach out to each other, to visit each other. I think it would have added greatly to my experience if, as part of PLC duties, I had to visit one other school and observe one of the volunteers teaching and report back to the group any differences I noticed between our styles of teaching and between our schools. As it was, I felt isolated from the group.    Lastly, the funding situation was confusing to me. I know that WorldTeach is undergoing major reorganization, but I thought it might be helpful to report from my perspective. As I understand it, we were each getting paid around 8,000 Baht, but our schools were paying WorldTeach around 24,000 Baht. If that is correct, I found this troubling for a few reasons. Compared to WorldTeach's competitors in Thailand, e.g., CIEE, other teachers doing much the same work, even in Nakhon Phanom, were getting paid basically the same thing our schools were paying WorldTeach. I know we are considered "volunteers" to WorldTeach, but our schools were paying us the equivalent of 2-3 full-time Thai teachers, so to them we weren't volunteers at all. If the schools' payments are to remain this high, I think the "volunteers" should get more of it -- perhaps 2/3 instead of 1/3, with the remaining 1/3 paying for the FD and admin/overhead. Or, preferably, reduce the school's payment substantially, and reduce the volunteer stipend as well. Otherwise, why should an applicant apply to WorldTeach instead of CIEE or Media Kids? The issue comes down to the mismatch between the schools' high contributions and the volunteers' low-ish stipends.    I hope this feedback is helpful. I don't mean it to be too negative. I really appreciate the support I've gotten from WorldTeach over the course of the year, and the opportunity to live and work in this beautiful place surrounded by friendly people.

column34: I had a lot of really special experiences in Ecuador. But I think the MOST memorable was the time I danced with some of the 10th graders from my school in a parade. One of my shoes broke, my sweat took almost all the glitter off the earrings I was wearing, and by the end of it, all of us were absolutely dead. That night, I honestly could not walk. I was hobbling around like a grandma, covered from head to toe in icy hot. column36: Definitely the hardest thing for me was living with a host family. I had the best host family in the world, and I have a great relationship with them. But being as independent as I am, it was really hard to be mothered by someone again. I figured the best solution was to try to meet somewhere in the middle. So, I explained in my best Spanish that Americans value a lot of independence and personal space, that when I needed it, I would go to my room, and that it didn't mean I was upset or angry or that something was wrong; it just meant I wanted to write in my journal or listen to music and have some alone time. I also said that if they ever felt like I was spending too much time alone, or if they worried about me, they could always talk to me about it, and never to feel uncomfortable talking to me about their concerns. I also bought a pack of playing cards, and tried to spend most nights playing a game after we cleaned up dinner, so we got to spend some family time together. I think for the most part, we did a pretty good job of managing family time and personal time, it just required a lot of effort and understanding on all of our parts.

column74: In the Peace Corps, the in-country staff partnered with a local elementary school, and we actually had a week long teaching practicum as part of our orientation. We were split into teaching pairs (one with more teaching experience and one with less), assigned a grade, given a textbook, and told to come up with a unit plan for the week. We co-taught our lessons to the students at the school. Each day we were observed by a different staff member and given feedback. And at the end of the week, we had a really long session dedicated to debriefing practicum. It was an awful lot of work, and I remember being extremely stressed out for that whole week, but it also gave all of us context to discuss all of the TEFL theory we were learning, and I learned so much in that week! I remember a lot of the fellows in the GEF saying the educational component of orientation was too much theory and not enough practice. I think finding some way to incorporate a teaching practicum into orientation would be helpful, not only because volunteers can learn a lot from it, but also from a retention standpoint. I think people were caught off-guard by some of the harsh realities of TEFL when they went to site and actually started teaching, and I think being able to pinpoint issues before sending volunteers to site could not only mean more and better-targeted support during orientation, but also if someone gets to country and realizes teaching just isn't for them during teaching practicum, they don't then go to site, quit halfway through, and potentially burn a bridge with a local partner school. Just food for thought!

column13: I felt WorldTeach expected a lot from us without giving us much back in return. Both Mid-Service and End of Service took up 3 days of our time, and each could have easily been done within a single afternoon more socially and organically without so much time wasted on forced bonding/sharing activities. There were a lot of expected deliverables that were poorly explained, often requiring multiple emails until concrete instructions were finally laid out. The weekly check-ins and travel texts felt like babysitting at best, and surveillance at worst. Whenever there was actually a real issue that I needed help with, somehow someone was always on vacation or couldn't do anything without asking several different people for permission to move forward. It seemed nothing ever got resolved, or I never got an actual answer better than "we'll look into it" unless I directly went straight to the Field Director for support. If it wasn't for the outstanding support and personal networks of my host family, I doubt I would have lasted even halfway through the program. Most if not all of us in the program felt that we were talked down to in condescending tones, whether in emails or during the conferences; we also felt like we were treated as if we were clueless children. It also was not helpful or reassuring to be given very overly optimistic and misleading information about our sites by people who've never lived in the communities. Not to mention, my host family was shocked and concerned after the Site Visit when they commented that the Assistant Field Director had very poor Spanish abilities, worse than the volunteer living with them who had only started conversing in Spanish when they arrived in November. I don't think it's the worst thing if volunteers arrive in country with rudimentary Spanish abilities since the goal is to communicate primarily in English, but you'd think the people who are supposed to be entrusted as our point of contact between WorldTeach and the Ecuadorian government would have completely fluent command of Spanish.

column38: Be ready and willing to do everything completely on your own, while still being incredibly flexible and open to help. Sometimes the people who are supposed to be able to help you won't be able to, while people you'd never imagine could possibly help are the ones who will save your sanity. It's important to always ask for help when you need it, and be patient, calm, and understanding when you do, whether you're asking WorldTeach or your host family or your community member for help or advice. No one will want to help you if you unleash all of your frustration or anger on them, or if you just complain and whine about your problems without giving some sort of hint in the right direction as to HOW this person could possibly offer a solution to your issue.
column40: I personally wish I had applied directly to the Time to Teach program instead of indirectly through WorldTeach. Maybe it's because I've already studied and worked abroad for extended time in a few different types of environments, but I found WorldTeach to be very overbearing without offering much support to make the difficult parts of the experience easier. I saw the stellar reputation online from past volunteers and the fact there was an orientation that promised strong teacher preparation and cultural orientation, but felt both lacking. When I had real problems that I needed external help with, I feel like WorldTeach always wanted me to wait to do anything when that's simply not possible when the school or Edificar would throw something on you at the last minute and expect you to go with it. Also, orientation seemed to spend more time on safety and behavior, which felt more like a checklist that the field staff was legally obligated to exhaustively go through so that volunteers would not be able to litigate if something terrible happened, then on actual teacher training or cultural preparation. It seemed to boil down to "lesson planning will save your life" without giving us any real examples applicable to the Ecuadorian culture or the rural education system as many of the techniques advised simply don't work here. I talked to as many of the volunteers with professional teaching experience prior to WorldTeach about their classrooms, and the consensus seemed to be that the techniques or approaches sensitive to the students' needs and lives that would work back home in the US were ineffective here. Likewise, many of the practical advice offered in PLCs were impossible due to resource restrictions, like decorating your classroom to subtly define it as your territory with your rules or showing up to class before the students; neither possible in schools where the students stay in the same classroom all day and the teachers rotate every class period. It just seems overall there was a huge disconnect between the well-meaning, optimistic, and largely theoretical approaches of WorldTeach to teaching in Ecuador, and the actual realities of doing that job in poor areas with limited resources and many administrative and disciplinary challenges.
column46: I don't think a questionnaire with vague responses and unclear instructions is really the best assessment of someone's intercultural competence. After speaking with Karen about the IDI test itself and the unclear questions, I realized I would have approached the questions completely differently. I tried to answer everything honestly, and some questions I that definitely lowered my score were ones that I disagreed with because I misinterpreted the meaning of the question. The tasks I was assigned to complete in order to mover on to the next section of the IDI assessment seemed repetitive and like backtracking as many of the things suggested were things I had done months earlier when I arrived. Maybe if we didn't have the TEFL and the PLCs and the project to worry about while juggling it with teaching responsibilities and personal lives, I would have dedicated more time to it. But as things happened, it fell to the bottom of my list of priorities because it seemed like unnecessary homework on top of everything else.

I had students from the younger classes begging me to stay on as their teacher the next few years until they graduate the middle school, and even bad students saying I was their favorite teacher/class so I averaged out both responses to 'Agree.' I give in immediately, the glued horde haphazardly guiding me across the uneven stubble of concrete and mud.  (Let the record show, I only sank into a pile of mud once.) Then, rapid little fists on the metal latch. Hushes from within. Click. Open, swinging. Before a full half of my foot has even hit the threshold, they usher me blindly into a chair, give me the go ahead to open my eyes, and burst: "Surprise!!!"    I opened my eyes to my hive of 4th graders pouring over and around me... They brought me presents, gave speeches, and contributed ingredients for a homemade birthday cake. My heart fought failing, while my eyes fought melting. I had never been so far from home on my birthday, but I am not sure I have ever felt more loved than in those moments.    I ditched the lesson plan. Erased the board. And cut the cake.

column13: I recommend that field staff receive better training and/or have more relevant job experience before being hired. There was a lack of professionalism, ability to be reactive, and general lack of empathy in dealing with volunteer situations. I felt that the staff was excellent at planning events that had plenty of preparation time such as Mid-service and End of Service conferences. However, generally the field staff struggled with uncertainty and reacting to the unexpected which would describe most situations given the pilot nature of the program. There was a point during orientation when we were filling out a visa form and following Lindsay's instruction. While we filled out the form, volunteers pointed out the variation in information she was giving us from the information she had previously sent us. She repeatedly said that she knew what she was doing defensively. The issue was not whether she was knowledgeable or not. The issue was how she was carrying herself and responding to volunteers. She was impatient, defensive and generally left a bad first impression on all of us from the beginning. On the flip side, Lindsay was empathetic with the many volunteers who fell ill during orientation and did a great job supporting us. I did not feel that I was adequately supported when I was mugged outside of my home. I received a call immediately following my mugging and I mentioned that my local phone was stolen from me the previous Friday while my iphone and laptop had just been taken from me. As I was incredibly emotionally distressed, I don't think it was an appropriate time to immediately point out WT policy requiring me to have a telephone even though there were only a few weeks left in the program. That night I sent Mecca an email stating that I was considering leaving the program since this was the 3rd time I was robbed. In the future I would recommend a reply email along the lines of: I'm sorry to hear about what you have gone through. I understand your feelings and will respect anything you decide to do. Please take some time for yourself and keep me posted on how I can help you. I would recommend you give yourself a day to think clearly because you've been through something traumatic.     Instead I got an immediate reply asking me whether this would be an early termination or would I be attending End of Service. Personally I like Mecca but in a program where most of the communication takes place via email then phone, I think she needs to understand how to convey empathy. It was literally the most scared I had ever been and that was not the support and/or words I needed via telephone or email. I also never received a follow up for the WT incident report and I'm surprised that WT didn't even offer to move me considering that their was a pair waiting on my street who robbed me outside of my home. I'm surprised that WT was never interested to hear what happened to me from my own mouth. It was overall disappointing to say the least.

column34: One of my most memorable class sessions was a class when I introduced a new review game. All of my classes enjoyed the game but one class in particular was enthralled by it. During the game the students worked in teams to race some fomx fish across waves on the board by answering review questions. The energy in the room was palpable and even my reserved students were rapidly flipping through their notebooks to find the answer, or arguing with their teammates about the correct answer. It was a blast! The students took missed answers with grace and were determined to know the next question correctly. I will never forget the uproar when the final group won and how they begged to play again (we did play again on another day of course). My heart was so full to see them taking such an active interest in making sure they knew the answer. I will also never forget the first time I experienced a ‚Äúvolcano drill‚Äù at school. Back home in Ohio I have participated in countless tornado drills but never did I consider the possibility of or the hilarity of a volcano drill. Watching the rows of students with hands on their heads walking into the center of the school compound, sirens blaring for the first time I had no idea what was going on, I could only chuckle to myself ‚Äòonly in Ecuador‚Äô and walk with my hands on my head too.   While in Ecuador I greatly enjoyed spending my weekends traveling. After spending the past year in Guyana, where in country travel was expensive and difficult due to a lack of development I was shocked and excited by how easy travel in Ecuador is. Because the country is so small I doesn‚Äôt take very long to get from one place to another. My favorite moment in Ecuador was on one of my weekend adventures, this particular time to Tena. While visiting other volunteers in the beautiful Amazon we found our way to Puyo and a giant jungle swing. I have never felt joy like I did with the wind rushing through my hair as I swung out over the rainforest. This memory will stay with me for a lifetime, a constant reminder to take the leap because the joy that follows is worth getting over the initial fear

In general, I feel like the staff was ill prepared for our arrival and the communication that needed to happen prior to us arriving in our community (including with the schools and host families) didn't happen, and when this caused problems (which it did), the staff was too overwhelmed to handle it properly. The way I see it, the reason to teach through a program like World Teach is to have the organization arrange the logistics and that just didn't happen adequately.
column20: Honestly, given the lack of cultural preparation and support, I feel like the constant stress and lack of appreciation from being part of this program might actually have taken a toll and decreased these characteristics.
column33: I wished I'd known how ill-prepared they would have been for us, that they didn't actually have individual communication with our principals prior to sending us to our sites, that the training wouldn't involve any meaningful components about Ecuadorian culture in general and within the schools specifically, that there was a possibility that we would be co-teachers rather than having our own classes and that the government had recently implemented this range of educational reforms, which meant that every single primary school student was in their first year of learning English and that my teaching experience and preferences wouldn't be taken into consideration when assigning school placements.
column34: My most memorable experiences in Ecuador all involve interaction with my students. In particular, I had a student named Mart√≠n who developed a lot as a student. He was in the seventh grade and at the beginning of the term he had a hard time focusing and remembering vocabulary and always seemed overwhelmed during class. But then, we started developing a personal connection, and he started trying harder and putting in a visible effort for each class. He also folded me a number of pieces of origami, which he gave to me as gifts, and which seemed to mark a turning point in his learning English. But the end of the year, he would light up whenever he saw me, sit at the front of the class, listening attentively and actively participating, and improving his scores gradually, but consistently. During my last month, he also started asking me questions about words he was interested and keeping his own mini personal vocabulary list, separate from what we were learning in class, which he would check with me each class. He's one of the clearest examples of the positive impact that I had on my students.
column35: I learned that I can do good work even in very trying circumstances, that I will speak up on behalf of myself and my colleagues when I feel like things aren't being done right or we aren't being respected, and that I am stubborn enough to finish my commitments, even when they are challenging.
column36: The most challenging aspect of this was feeling exploited and under appreciated. The benefits of participating in this program absolutely were not worth the amount of stress and effort that I had to put in. While I fulfilled all of my requirements, from teaching more hours than were required, completing the same duties that would be expected from an Ecuadorian teacher and creating a quite detailed, thorough projects, I felt like I didn't get adequate recognition from either my school or from the staff of World Teach. I dealt with this by talking to my fellow fellows, who did appreciate my presence here, and focusing on the classes that most clearly showed that they liked having me there.
column37: Willingness to engage in self-advocacy. There were so many problems with this programs, and no one else proactively checked that things were going smoothly, so you really need to be willing to speak up for yourself.
column38: Clarify every single one of your expectations with the staff before agreeing to come. Make sure you're ok with their interpretation of what they're offering and don't assume your understanding of the program is the same as the staff's.
column40: I have taught in a range of places and programs and I have never had a more difficult, less fulfilling experience than I have had here. This program is contributing to the deprofessionalization of EFL teaching and does not adequately support participants, so I would actively warn anyone I knew not to participate.

column74: The Office of Education just didn't do much, and none of it felt like it was directed at a teacher of my level. While initially I really enjoyed my PLC and found it to be productive, after the first month both of the other members in it resigned from the program, which left me with no one else in my region who was interested in taking the PLC seriously. All of the other professional educators were placed in different regions, which made it difficult to have conversations that were meaningful during the PLC, so I would recommend that the program space teachers with extensive experience more evenly throughout the country, so that we can develop through interactions with our peers in addition to helping less experienced teachers develop. The Office of Education was also very uncommunicative and it felt like no one actually cared about our projects.
column78: I had a lovely host family set up, that gave me both a local base of support and enough independence and privacy, in addition to healthy food.  My town was fine in and of itself, but the other fellows placed near me did not provide a good network of support. I felt like the groups placed in other regions were much more cohesive.  I had to fight to get a teaching assignment from my school that was reasonable and worth spending my time on. Initially I was asked to do things that were ridiculous (like co-teach lterally 25 different classes for one class a week each with 10 different co-teachers), instead of being given a reasonable schedule. I also felt like my experience was not appreciated and my professionalism was not respected by my school when it came to negotiating my teaching assignment, which was incredibly stressful.
column80: The living stipend would have been fine if I was single, but given that my husband had to pay extra for the exact same housing arrangement as me, it was insufficient.
column81: I wouldn't recommend anyone with a dependent participate in this program at all. But if they did, at least an extra $400 dollars a month.

column53: College Fair Recruiter: Help represent WorldTeach at recruiting events sponsored by colleges and universities. We will send you the necessary information and materials to display at the event including a sign-up sheet, flyers and other WorldTeach materials. Your role would be to prepare a table to display, share your experience with potential candidates, have them sign up to be contacted in the future for WorldTeach program information, and follow up with a brief fair evaluation. The family party showed me how important family is in Ecuadorian culture. I love the way of using dancing to express that love and care. It was unforgettable.
column35: This year I challenged myself to do things that scared me. I was usually rewarded with a really fun experience, a rich friendship, or a moment of gaining knowledge. I hope I can continue that approach to the things I do after my year in WorldTeach is over.

I did not, however, find the PLCs to be useful and was very frustrated when I expressed my suggestions and concerns at mid-service and did not feel that they were taken seriously. Rather than adjusting the PLC structure so as to make it more organic and helpful to a range of classes and situations, we were simply told that we did not have to report any aspects of the PLC (basically prompting us to not do them at all). This, to me, was not a thoughtful way to improve the PLC.
column80: Yes, but I was a little irritated that I had entered the program with the understanding that all three meals would be covered by half of the stipend, only to find out during the orientation that lunch (the largest meal of the day) was no longer covered. column37: I think a lot of different sorts of people can come out here and have really successful experiences with this program. But you definitely need to be flexible and open to doing things and working well outside your comfort zone. You have to be patient and willing to look silly, and you have to love kids. And even if you're not a glass-half-full kind of person, you have to constantly tell yourself that you are. A positive outlook is pretty important. That's what's going to allow you to get through the bad stuff and enjoy the good, and walk away from this experience as a more fulfilled person.
column38: WorldTeach is a great program for anyone interested in getting out of their regular routine and doing some good at the same time. You don't have to have a load of experience teaching, just a willingness to learn and to make mistakes (and learn from those as well). The complete apathy by the community and many of the other teachers also made any type of support system difficult.  I confronted this challenge by trying my best to just focus on giving my students the best experience possible with the time that I had with them. column37: Volunteers need to be extremely flexible and have a strong degree of emotional stability in their lives.  I think this is especially important when the volunteers are placed on the more remote outer islands.
column38: I would suggest that only people who are at a stable point in their lives (mentally, emotionally, interpersonally) consider coming to the Outer Islands.  It is not a place to "run away from your problems."  I would also suggest looking into teaching resources and ideas, especially if you have little or no teaching experience.  Finally, I would highly recommend making a concentrated effort to learning the local language both before you arrive, during orientation, and throughout your period of service. column81: I never found money to be a problem, but I know it was a big problem for some of the other volunteers. column82: I took the initiative to create three after school programs to meet the needs of the students that could not be met within the regular classroom. The first was a phonics reading program for students who did not know how to read. In this program, the students watched phonics videos, practiced phonics, and memorized sight word flash cards. The second program was a low-level reading program for students who could read, but far below their grade level. Here, the students practiced reading books as other adults and I read with them, corrected their pronunciation and assessed their comprehension of the material. Finally, the third program was a critical and creative thinking program for high-achieving students. In this program, I challenged the students with critical and creative thinking activities to foster higher-level thinking and advanced approaches to processing information.    All three programs were successful, though the first two were started earlier and saw more success than the third program. The second program (low-level readers) was the most successful as students were able to receive 1-on-1 attention that they could not find in the classroom. This gave students a little extra push to work hard and succeed. Consistency also effected the success of the programs. The more consistency, the more success.

column20: My roommate and I took to open water swimming as a catharsis and athletic outlet. We quickly realized, however, that swimming was just a more contained and controllable analogy of our experiences as volunteers. Through training, we became comfortable and more adept at handling the difficulties and dangers of the open waters. However, the phantom danger of sharks and rip tides were constant reminders that every time we entered the water we trespassed in another a world--a world outside of our element. When you live and teach on a remote island, you are always outside of your element. What is important, is learning how to float. WorldTeach was instrumental in giving us the training and constant support needed to not just float, but swim as teachers. The field director offered constant emotional and professional support, which functioned as a lifeline when necessary. Although it was difficult at times, I learned most from trial and error this year, from being thrown into a classroom environment and each day trying something new to see what was the best way to reach my students.
